Abandonment of opposition under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017
Deemed abandonment due to failure to adduce evidence in support of opposition within prescribed time frame
Validity of notice of counter statement served electronically on the appellant
Effectiveness of waiver by the opponent if they choose to rely solely on facts stated in the notice of opposition
Interpretation of Rule 45(1) of the Trade Marks Rules regarding submission of evidence and intent to rely on facts stated in the notice of opposition
Timeliness of opposition under Rule 42 of the Trade Marks Rules, which may affect respondent's right to oppose registration
Presumption that applicant has a prima facie valid application for trade mark registration
Burden of proof on the opponent to demonstrate the grounds relied upon for opposition
Whether trade mark "LIVGUARD ZING" is likely to be confused with appellant's existing or registered marks
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022 & I.A. 179/2023**

**Background:**
The case involves an appeal by M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd (Appellant) against the order of the Deputy Registrar of Trademarks (Respondent 1) dated August 2018, rejecting their opposition to the registration of a trade mark "LIVGUARD ZING" (Trade Mark Application No. 2772497) filed by Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt. Ltd (Respondent 2). The Appellant's opponent was deemed abandoned under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017.

**Legal Issues:**

1. Whether the Respondents' trade mark "LIVGUARD ZING" can be registered when there is an ongoing opposition by the Appellant?
2. Did the Respondents comply with the provisions of Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017?
3. Was the Appellant's opponent deemed abandoned under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017?

**Arguments:**

Appellant:
* Argued that the Respondents failed to provide evidence in support of their application for registration.
* Contended that the Respondent's trade mark "LIVGUARD ZING" was similar to their registered trade mark and would cause confusion among consumers.

Respondents (R-1 & R-2):
* Argued that they complied with Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 by filing a counter statement in response to the Appellant's notice of opposition.
* Contended that the Appellant's opponent was deemed abandoned due to non-compliance with Rule 45(2).

**Court Findings:**

1. **Mis-construction of Rule 45:** The Court found that Rule 45 is poorly worded, making it unclear how an application for evidence should be filed.
2. **Non-compliance by Respondents (R-1 & R-2):** Despite serving the counter statement on August 7th, 2018, the respondents failed to provide evidence in support of their trade mark application within the two-month timeframe stipulated under Rule 45(2).
3. **Deemed Abandonment:** As a result of the respondents' non-compliance with Rule 45(2), their opponent (Appellant) was deemed abandoned under Rule 45.

**Decision:**
The Court upheld the decision of the Deputy Registrar of Trademarks and ruled that:

1. The opposition to Respondent 2's trade mark application is deemed abandoned under Rule 45(2).
2. There shall be no order as to costs in these proceedings.

In conclusion, this case involved a dispute over the registration of a trade mark "LIVGUARD ZING" by Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt. Ltd. The High Court held that the Respondents' non-compliance with Rule 45(2) rendered their opponent (Appellant) abandoned, and therefore, they did not have standing to oppose the Registration of Trade Marks in this case

IT IS HEREBY FURTHER ORDERED that there shall be

2. 
Given the nature of the controversy in the present case, it is not 
necessary to enter into the specifics of the application seeking 
registration.  
 
3. 
Suffice it to state that the application for registration was filed 
by Respondent 2 on 11th July 2014, and was published in the Register 
of Trade Marks on 15th February 2016 inviting opposition and that, on 
2nd June 2016, notice of opposition was filed by the appellant before 
the learned Registrar.  Counter statement, in response to the notice of 
opposition filed by the appellant was filed by the Respondent 2 on 7th 
March 2018.  It is an admitted position that, on the same day i.e., 7th
 
 
March 2018, the notice of counter statement filed by Respondent 2 
was served electronically on the appellant.  
4. 
Rule 45 of the Trade Marks Rules reads thus: 
“45. 
Evidence in support of opposition.— (1) Within two 
months from  service of a copy of the counterstatement, the 
opponent shall either leave with the Registrar, such evidence by 
way of affidavit as he may desire to adduce in support of his 
opposition or shall intimate to the Registrar and to the applicant in 
writing that he does not desire to adduce evidence in support of his 
opposition but intends to rely on the facts stated in the notice of 
opposition. He shall deliver to the applicant copies of any evidence 
including exhibits, if any, that he leaves with the Registrar under 
this sub-rule and intimate the Registrar in writing of such delivery. 
 
If an opponent takes no action under sub-rule (1) within the 
time mentioned therein, he shall be deemed to have abandoned his 
opposition.” 
 
 
5. 
At a plain glance, Rule 45 is very unhappily worded. It uses the 
expression “leave with the Registrar”. This is an expression to which 
Digitally Signed

Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137

                                                       Page 3 of 9  
 
   
no legal interpretation can possibly be given.  
 
6. 
My attention has been invited to Rule 8 of the Trade Mark 
Rules which deals with “leaving of documents” etc. and reads thus: 
“8. 
Leaving of documents, etc.— All applications, notices, 
statements or other documents or any fees authorised or required 
by the Act or the rules to be made, served, left or sent or paid at or 
to the Trade Marks Registry in relation to a trademark on the 
Register of trademarks on the notified date or for which an 
application for registration is pending on, or is made on or after the 
notified date, shall be made, served, left or sent or paid to the 
appropriate office of the Trade Marks Registry: 
 
Provided that the Registrar may, by notification in the journal, 
permit the filing of certain forms or documents, other than the 
application for the registration of a trademark in any other office of 
the Trade Marks Registry.” 
 
7. 
Unfortunately, Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules is just as 
nebulous as Rule 45.  It requires the opponent, opposing the 
registration of a trade mark, to “leave with the Registrar”, evidence by 
way of affidavit.  It is difficult to understand the expression “leave 
with the Registrar”.  At any rate, it is not an expression which should 
ordinarily find place in a legislative document. 
 
8. 
The case of the appellant, as argued by Ms. Bhabna Das, 
learned Counsel for the appellant, and as set out in the present appeal, 
is that 7th May 2018 being the last date by which the evidence in 
opposition was required to be filed by the appellant, attempts were 
made to upload the evidence on the website of the Registrar of Trade 
Marks, but that, as the website was non-functional, this could not be 
done.  As a result, submits Ms. Bhabna Das, the evidence was sent to 
the office of the Registrar by courier.  It is an admitted position that 
the evidence in opposition as sent by the appellant was, in fact, 
received by the office of the learned Registrar on 10th May 2018, i.e., 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 4 of 9  
 
   
mere three days beyond the last date for “leaving” of the evidence.  
 
9. 
As is apparent, the impugned order has proceeded on the 
premise that, as the evidence in terms of Rule 45 of the Trade Mark 
Rules had not been filed within two months from the service of the 
counter statement of Respondent 2 on the appellant, the opposition of 
the appellant was deemed to have been abandoned by application of 
sub-rule (2) of Rule 45.  
 
10. 
At a bare glance, the impugned order is incorrect, as Rule 45(1) 
does not use the expression “filed”.  What Rule 45(1) requires is that 
the evidence must be “left with the Registrar”.  Where the statute is 
ambiguous, the benefit of ambiguity has to go to the citizen. This 
would be especially so where the statute confers a valuable 
commercial right on the citizen. It cannot be gainsaid that, having 
submitted the notice of opposition, opposing the application of 
Respondent 2 for registration of the Trade Mark, the tendering of 
evidence in support of the opposition was a valuable commercial right 
which enured in favor of the opponent/appellant. There is no 
conceivable reason as to why, having filed the notice of opposition, 
the appellant would abandon the opposition.  That the appellant did 
not, in fact, do so, is manifest by the fact that, on 28th
 
 August 2018, 
the appellant filed an application for extension of time, purportedly 
under Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act read with Rule 109 of the 
Trade Mark Rules, in Form TM-M, as required by the said rules.  
11. 
The application has not been considered by the learned Deputy 
Registrar while passing the impugned order. In the application, it was 
specifically submitted that the website of the learned Registrar of 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 5 of 9  
 
   
Trade Marks was non-functional on 7th May 2018, as a result of 
which, on 8th
 
 May 2018, the evidence in opposition was sent by the 
appellant by courier.  
12. 
As already noticed, it is an admitted position that the evidence 
in opposition was indeed received by the office of the learned 
Registrar on 10th
 
 May 2018.     
13. 
The issue before the court is whether, in these circumstances 
and in the backdrop of the existing statutory scenario as contained in 
the Trade Marks Act and Trade Marks Rules, this Court should sustain 
the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar, vide the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018, to treat the opposition filed by the appellant, 
to the application of Respondent 2 seeking registration of the 
“LIVGUARD ZING” mark, as having been abandoned.  
14. 
Having heard Ms. Bhabna Das, learned Counsel for the 
appellant and Mr. Jithin M George, learned Counsel for Respondent 2, 
in my considered opinion, the answer to this query has necessarily to 
be in the negative.  
 
15. 
Two issues would arise for consideration. The first is whether 
there was, in fact, delay on the part of the appellant in complying with 
the requirement of Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules. The second is 
whether, assuming there was any such delay, the learned Registrar 
was empowered to condone the delay or to extend the time for 
compliance with Rule 45.  
 
16. 
Addressing the first issue first, Rule 45 (1) stipulates that, 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 6 of 9  
 
   
within two months from service of the copy of the counter statement 
filed by the trade mark applicant, the opponent opposing the 
registration of the mark is required to leave, with the Registrar, 
evidence by way of affidavit in support of the opposition.  Rule 45(1) 
further requires the opponent to the registration of the trade mark to 
deliver, to the applicant seeking registration, copies of the affidavit 
left with the Registrar and to intimate the Registrar in that regard.   
 
17. 
Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules states that all documents, which 
are required “to be made, served, left or sent or paid at or to the Trade 
Marks Registry”, in respect of a Trade Mark in respect of which an 
application seeking registration is pending, “shall be made, served, 
left, or sent or paid to the appropriate office of the Trade Marks 
Registry”. 
 
18. 
As already observed, the provision is as nebulous as can be.  
The Rule, envelops, in one parenthesis, the expressions “made” 
“served”, “left”, “sent” and “paid” and refers to such making, serving, 
leaving, sending, or paying “to the appropriate office of the Trade 
Marks Registry”. 
 
19. 
Given the nature of these provisions and the fact that they affect 
a valuable right vested in an opponent who seeks to oppose the 
registration of a trade mark, I am of the considered opinion that, in the 
facts of the present case, the appellant won’t be entitled to the benefit 
of the ambiguity inherent in this provision.  
 
20. 
The appellant, in its application seeking extension of time as 
filed before the learned Deputy Registrar, as well as in the present 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 7 of 9  
 
   
appeal, has stated, on affidavit, that the attempts at e-filing of the 
evidence in support of the appellant’s objections, on 7th
 
 May 2018, 
could not succeed as the website of the learned Registrar of Trade 
Marks was non-functional.  The impugned order does not seek to 
discountenance this assertion.  Notice was issued in the present 
appeal, and there is no affidavit filed by way of response, denying this 
fact.  
21. 
There is no reason, therefore, for this Court to disbelieve the 
appellant and presume that, in fact, no attempt was made by the 
appellant to e-file the objections on 7th May 2018, especially as, on the 
very next day i.e., 8th May 2018, the objections were in fact sent by 
courier.  This is not, therefore, a case in which the appellant exhibited 
any callous or negligent indolence.   The fact that, on 8th May 2018, 
the appellant did indeed courier the evidence in support of the 
opposition to the office of the learned Registrar of Trade Marks, 
compels this Court to believe the assertion, in the present appeal, also 
contained in the application for extension of time filed before the 
learned Registrar with the evidence in support of the opposition was in 
fact forwarded to the office of the learned Registrar electronically on 
7th
 
 May 2018, but that the attempt could not succeed as the website 
was non-functional.  
22. 
Such an attempt, in my view, would fall within the broad 
embrace of the expression “made, served, left, sent or paid to the 
appropriate office of the Trade Marks Registry”, as employed in Rule 
8 of the Trade Marks Rules.  
 
23. 
Even otherwise, it is well-settled that, while procedural 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 8 of 9  
 
   
provisions are required to be accorded their due deference, they cannot 
be interpreted so rigidly as to result in evisceration of substantive 
rights vested in the citizens. The right to oppose registration of a trade 
mark is just as sacrosanct as the right to seek registration. In the 
peculiar facts of the present case once the application for opposition 
had actually been filed by the appellant, it would be entirely unfair for 
this Court to uphold the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar to 
treat the opposition as having been abandoned only because the 
evidence in support of the opposition was received three days late, 
especially as, prima facie, the appellant did make efforts to “leave” the 
evidence in support of the opposition with the office of the learned 
Registrar  within the time stipulated in that regard in Rule 45(1) of the  
Trade Marks Rules. 
 
24. 
In that view of the matter, this Court is not required to examine 
the somewhat more nuanced issue of whether, where the evidence in 
opposition is not “left” with the office of the learned Registrar within 
two months as envisaged in Rule 45(1), any discretion vests in the 
learned Registrar to extend the time therefor.   That would involve a 
juxtaposed interpretation of Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act and 
Rules 8, 45 and 109 of the Trade Marks Rules, which may be left for 
another sunny evening.   
 
25. 
In the facts of the present case, therefore, the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018 would stand set aside.  
26. 
Resultantly, the learned Deputy Registrar is directed to take into 
account the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant and take a 
view thereon.  
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:10.01.2023
11:21:49
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000137 
 C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022  
                                                       Page 9 of 9  
 
   
27. 
I am informed that, after the impugned order was passed, the 
mark of Respondent 2 has proceeded to registration.  
 
28. 
Needless to say, in view of the decision taken today, the 
registration of the Trade Mark shall remain subject to the outcome of 
the view to be taken by the learned Deputy Registrar on the opposition 
filed by the appellant.  
 
29. 
In order that equities are not unnecessarily prejudiced, the  
learned Deputy Registrar is directed to take a decision on the 
appellant's notice of opposition, after following due process in that 
regard, within a period of three months from today.  
 
30. 
For this purpose, both sides are directed to present themselves 
before the office of the learned Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks on 
16th
 
 January 2023 at 11:00 a.m. 
31. 
The learned Deputy Registrar would proceed with the matter 
with all due expedition.  
 
32. 
Both sides are directed not to seek any adjournment from the 
learned Deputy Registrar. 
 
33. 
The appeal stands allowed accordingly with no order as to 
costs.  
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J. 
 
JANUARY 6, 2023

**Case Summary: MS V-Guard Industries Ltd vs The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.**

**PDF Source:** [36. MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf](https://pdfcoffee.com/pdf-to-html/8m6u39w3q0/ms-v-guard-industries-ltd-vs-the-registrar-of-trade-marks--)

**Case Details:**

* **Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/000137
* **C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022**: Appeal case number
* **Date of Order:** 06.01.2023

**Parties:**

* **Appellant (Plaintiff):** M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd.
	+ Represented by Ms. Babna Das, Mr. Mukul Kumar, and Mr. Vizzy George
* **Respondents (Defendants):**
	1. The Registrar of Trademarks
	2. M/s Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd. (Respondent 2 or Respondent "R-2")

**Background:**

The appeal was filed against an order of the Deputy Registrar of Trademarks, dismissing the opposition by V-Guard Industries Ltd to the registration of the mark "LIVGUARD ZING" by Livguard Energy Technologies Pvt Ltd.

**Facts and Arguments:**

* V-Guard Industries Ltd. opposed the registration of the mark "LIVGUARD ZING" in February 2016.
* The opponent failed to file evidence in support of opposition within two months from service of the counterstatement (Rule 45 of Trade Marks Rules).
* Therefore, their opposition was deemed abandoned.

**Decision:**

The appeal was allowed. The court held that since V-Guard Industries Ltd did not file any evidence in support of opposition as required under Rule 45(1) of Trade Marks Rules, their opposition was deemed to have been abandoned

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi issued an order in C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022. The court ordered that there shall be no order as to costs in these proceedings.

The court then briefly discussed the application for registration of a trade mark by Respondent-2, filed on July 11, 2014, and published on February 15, 2016. Notice of opposition was filed by the Appellant (M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd) on June 2, 2016.

**Summary of Section: Background and Facts**

From the document MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf (2023/DHC/000137), we have:

**Background:**
M/S V-GUARD INDUSTRIES LTD, the appellant, filed a notice of opposition against THE REGISTRAR OF TRADEMARKS & ANR, the respondents, on March 1, 2018.

**Facts:**

* The last date for filing evidence in opposition was May 7, 2018.
* Due to a non-functional website, the appellant attempted to upload evidence but failed. Instead, they sent it via courier on May 9, 2018 (three days beyond the deadline).
* The evidence was received by the Registry office on May 10, 2018.

**Arguments:**

* The appellant argued that Rule 45(1) of the Trade Mark Rules requires leaving evidence with the Registrar, not filing it.
* The benefit of ambiguity should go to the citizen, and the statute confers a valuable commercial right on the opponent.

**Decisions:**
The impugned order was incorrect as it proceeded on the premise that Rule 45(1) required "filed" instead of "left with the Registrar".

**Parties:**

* M/S V-GUARD INDUSTRIES LTD (appellant)
* THE REGISTRAR OF TRADEMARKS & ANR. (respondent)

**Dates:**
March 1, 2018; May 7, 2018; May 9, 2018; May 10, 2018

Source:
MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf (2023/DHC/000137)

**Citation:** 2023/DHC/000137, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022
**Subject:** Trade Mark Rules and procedures

The court discusses two rules mentioned in the case:

1. **Rule 45**: Not specified, but considered unworkable.
2. **Rule 8 of the Trade Mark Rules**: Deals with "leaving of documents" etc. States that applications, notices, statements or other documents shall be made, served, left or sent to the Trade Marks Registry.

The court finds both rules uncertain and open to interpretation. Specifically, it questions the meaning of "leave with the Registrar" in Rule 8.

**Key Facts:**

* The case revolves around a trade mark opposition case.
* Evidence was required to be filed by May 7, 2018.
* Due to website issues, evidence was sent via courier on May 10, 2018.
* It is admitted that the evidence was received by the registrar's office on May 10, 2018.

**Key points:**

* The impugned order deemed the appellant's opposition to have been abandoned due to failure to file evidence within two months.
* Rule 45(1) of the Trade Mark Rules requires the evidence to be "left with the Registrar", not filed.
* This ambiguity is resolved in favor of the citizen, as filing a notice of opposition confers a valuable commercial right.
* The appellant submitted an application for extension of time on August 28, 2018, but this was not considered by the Deputy Registrar.

tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary:**

**Case Title:** MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.

**Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/000137 

**Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi

**Parties:**

* Appellant: M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd.
* Respondents: The Registrar of Trademarks and Another (Respondent 2)

**Background:**
The appellant opposed the registration of the "LIVGUARD ZING" mark by Respondent 2. The evidence in support of the opposition was sent to the Register of Trade Marks on May 8, 2018.

**Legal Arguments:**

* The issue before the court is whether the appellant's opposition should be treated as abandoned due to delay in complying with Rule 45 of the Trade Mark Rules.
* The court finds that there is no provision for condoning or extending time for compliance under the Trade Marks Act and Rules.
* The rules require all documents to be made, served, left, or sent to the Trade Marks Registry within a specified timeframe.

**Decision:**

* The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi held that the learned Deputy Registrar erred in treating the opposition as abandoned due to delay in compliance with Rule 45.
* The court upheld the rights of the opponent under the Trade Marks Act and Rules, noting that the provisions are designed to protect a valuable right vested in an opponent.

**Date:**

* May 7, 2018 (evidence sent by courier)
* May 10, 2018 (evidence received by the office of the Register of Trade Marks)
* August 30, 2018 (impugned order dated)

**References:** 
See PDF "MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf"

Here is a summary of page 6 from the document in under 200 words:

**Case Details**

* Case Number: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000137
* Document source: MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr (PDF: 36)

**Summary**

Page 6 mentions the following key points:

* Under Rule 45(1), an opponent opposing trade mark registration must leave evidence with the Registrar within two months.
* The opponent must also deliver copies of the affidavit to the applicant and intimate the Registrar about this delivery.
* Rule 8 states that all documents related to a pending trade mark application should be "made, served, left, or sent" to the appropriate Trade Marks Registry office.

**Relevant Points**

Rule 45(1) requires an opponent to take certain actions in response to a trade mark application. The court notes that these provisions are somewhat ambiguous but relevant to determining whether the appellant (V-Guard Industries Ltd.) can benefit from this ambiguity.

nodes.summary:
Here's a summary of page 7 from the PDF:

The appellant (M/S V-Guard Industries Ltd) claims that they attempted to e-file evidence in support of their objections on May 7, 2018, but were unable to do so because the Registrar of Trade Marks' website was non-functional. The court accepts this assertion as true and notes that a response affidavit from the respondent denying this fact is not filed.

The court also observes that on the next day (May 8, 2018), the appellant sent the evidence by courier. This suggests that the appellant did indeed make an attempt to e-file the objections, which is considered sufficient under Rule 8 of the Trade Marks Rules.

The court's decision is based on the following:

* The appellant provided affidavit evidence supporting their claim.
* No response from the respondent denying this fact was filed.
* The next-day delivery of the evidence by courier indicates that an earlier electronic attempt was made, which failed due to technical issues.

tree_structure.summary:
**Court Decision: MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.**

**Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/000137 

**C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022 & I.A. 179/2023**

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard this appeal on January 6, 2023.

**Facts and Parties:**

* Appellant: MS V-Guard Industries Ltd.
* Respondents: The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.
* Opponent's evidence was received three days late due to efforts made to "leave" it with the office of the learned Registrar within the stipulated time in Rule 45(1) of the Trade Marks Rules.

**Court Decision:**

The court set aside the impugned order dated August 30, 2018, and directed the Deputy Registrar to take into account the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant. The registration of Respondent 2's trade mark is subject to the outcome of the view to be taken by the learned Deputy Registrar on the opposition.

**Decision:**

The appeal was allowed with no order as to costs. Both sides are directed not to seek any adjournment from the learned Deputy Registrar, and the matter must proceed with all due expedition. The Deputy Registrar is to take a decision on the appellant's notice of opposition within three months from January 6, 2023.

**PDF Source:** MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr., C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2022 & I.A. 179/2023 (2023/DHC/000137), High Court of Delhi at New Delhi, January 6, 2023.

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 8 from the provided PDF (MS V-Guard Industries Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr.pdf) [1] :

The court opined that **Rule 45(1)** of the Trade Marks Rules, which requires evidence in opposition to be left with the office of the learned Registrar within two months, must not be interpreted so rigidly as to result in evisceration of substantive rights. The court noted that the appellant had made efforts to submit the evidence on time and that it was received three days late.

The court distinguished between **Rule 45(1)** (requirement for evidence submission) and **Section 131** of the Trade Marks Act, under which discretion may be exercised if the learned Registrar deems fit. However, in this case, no such discretion had been applied.

**Decision**: The court set aside the impugned order dated August 30, 2018, directing the Deputy Registrar to consider the evidence in opposition and form a view accordingly.

Date: Reference is not provided on the exact date on page 8 but, the signing date of the digitally signed document is January 10, 2023.

be interpreted so rigidly as to result in evisceration of substantive 
rights vested in the citizens. The right to oppose registration of a trade 
mark is just as sacrosanct as the right to seek registration. In the 
peculiar facts of the present case once the application for opposition 
had actually been filed by the appellant, it would be entirely unfair for 
this Court to uphold the decision of the learned Deputy Registrar to 
treat the opposition as having been abandoned only because the 
evidence in support of the opposition was received three days late,

Registrar  within the time stipulated in that regard in Rule 45(1) of the  
Trade Marks Rules. 
 
24. 
In that view of the matter, this Court is not required to examine 
the somewhat more nuanced issue of whether, where the evidence in 
opposition is not “left” with the office of the learned Registrar within 
two months as envisaged in Rule 45(1), any discretion vests in the 
learned Registrar to extend the time therefor.   That would involve a 
juxtaposed interpretation of Section 131 of the Trade Marks Act and 
Rules 8, 45 and 109 of the Trade Marks Rules, which may be left for 
another sunny evening.   
 
25. 
In the facts of the present case, therefore, the impugned order 
dated 30th
 
 August 2018 would stand set aside.

account the evidence in opposition filed by the appellant and take a
